name: Patrolman Neil G. Thompson
bio: Patrolman Neil Thompson was killed when a suspect fleeing other officers in a stolen ambulance intentionally rammed his patrol car. Patrolman Thompson had pulled his marked squad car well off the travel portion of the roadway to avoid the oncoming speeding ambulance.  The driver swerved off the roadway and intentionally struck the officer's stopped patrol car. The 38-year-old suspect, who has been in and out of mental institutions for 17 years, was convicted of reckless homicide and vehicle theft. He was convicted under a new state law in which he was found guilty but insane. This gave officials the discretion of having him serve his 12 years in a prison, a mental hospital, or some of both. Patrolman Thompson was a United States Army veteran of the Vietnam War. He had served with the LaPorte County Police Department for three years. He was survived by his wife, parents, brother and sister. In 2002, State Road 39 from U.S. 6 to U.S. 30 in LaPorte County was dedicated the Neil G. Thompson Memorial Highway in his honor.
incident_details: Cause: Vehicular assault Weapon: Automobile Offender: Sentenced to 12 years

name: Patrolman Anthony Wagner
bio: Patrolman Anthony Wagner succumbed to wounds suffered over two weeks earlier when he was shot as he tried to stop a man at 116th Street and Atchison Avenue, believing he was involved in a robbery which had just occurred. Patrolman Wagner ordered the man to stop, but the suspect whose hands were in his overcoat pockets fired through the coat and struck Patrolman Wagner, who died from his wound more than two weeks later. Patrolman Wagner had served with the Whiting Police Department for six years. He was survived by his wife and two children.
incident_details: Cause: Gunfire Incident Date: Tuesday, November 12, 1929 Weapon: Gun; Unknown type Offender: Not available

name: Police Officer Jerrold Joseph "Jerry" Wyss
bio: Officer Jerrold Wyss was killed in an automobile accident while en route to back up another officer investigating a report of a vehicle whose occupants were firing a gun into a residence in rural Adams County. Officer Wyss' patrol car flipped over several times on U.S. 224 near the Indiana-Ohio border, ejecting him from the vehicle. The other officer chased the suspect vehicle into Ohio before calling off the pursuit. The suspects were never apprehended. Officer Wyss had served with the Decatur Police Department for three years. He was survived by his wife and 1-year-old son. In 2002, U.S. 224 from County Road 200 East to County Road 700 East in Adams County was dedicated the Jerrold J. Wyss Memorial Highway in his honor.
incident_details: Cause: Vehicle pursuit Weapon: Automobile Offender: Never apprehended

name: Trooper Scott Alan Patrick
bio: Trooper Scott Patrick was shot and killed at approximately 4:30 am when dispatched to assist a stranded motorist at the Grant Street exit of Interstate 80/94 in Gary in Lake County. Upon his arrival, Trooper Patrick saw the vehicle parked with two flat tires and observed a man walking up the nearby exit ramp. When Trooper Patrick approached to offer help, the suspect pulled a handgun and opened fire. Despite being shot above his bullet-resistant vest, once in the neck, Trooper Patrick was able to radio for assistance and return fire. He was unaware that the vehicle had been stolen the previous week and died less than a half-hour later while in surgery at Northlake Methodist Hospital. The suspect then hid behind the double set of tires of a flatbed trailer that had stopped at the scene. An assisting trooper arrived and was directed to where the suspect was hiding, who then fled on foot and jumped into the cab of another semitrailer. The suspect attempted to put the vehicle into gear and, after making threatening gestures toward the trooper, was shot multiple times but survived. At the time of the incident, the suspect was on parole for selling crack cocaine near a school and, although being sentenced to two years in prison, had been released after 90 days. The suspect was arrested and convicted of murder and auto theft. In July 2006, the suspect was sentenced to life in prison without parole. The Indiana Supreme Court, in June 2008, affirmed both the conviction and sentence of the offender. Trooper Patrick had served with the Indiana State Police for nearly 3Â½ years and was assigned to the Lowell post. He was survived by his wife, a son who was born six months after his death, parents, a sister, and two brothers. His father serves as chief deputy for the Pulaski County Sheriff's Department, one of his brothers serves as a conservation officer with the Indiana Department of Natural Resources, and his other brother serves as an officer with the Indiana State Excise Police. In 2006, State Road 10 between Wheatfield and DeMotte in Jasper County was dedicated as the Trooper Scott A. Patrick Memorial Highway in his honor.
incident_details: Cause: Gunfire Weapon: Handgun; .380 caliber Offender: Sentenced to life

name: Town Marshal Anthony Wayne Hinshaw
bio: Town Marshal Tony Hinshaw died as a result of contracting COVID-19 in the line of duty. Marshal Hinshaw was a United States Army veteran and had served with the Losantville Marshal's Office for nine years. He is survived by his wife and three children.
incident_details: Cause: COVID19 Incident Date: Thursday, October 14, 2021

name: Patrolman Anthony B. "Bud" Burton
bio: Officer Anthony Burton and Reserve Officer Lonnie Howard were killed when their patrol car was rammed by a man who was free on bond following an earlier standoff with police. The suspect was apprehended but committed suicide while awaiting trial. Officer Burton had served with the North Vernon Police Department for three years. He was survived by his wife, mother, sister and four brothers.
incident_details: Cause: Vehicular assault Weapon: Automobile Offender: Committed suicide

name: Reserve Officer Lonnie Edward Howard
bio: Reserve Officer Lonnie Howard and Officer Anthony Burton were killed when their patrol car was rammed by a man who was free on bond  following an earlier standoff with police. The suspect was apprehended but committed suicide while awaiting trial. Reserve Officer Howard had served with the North Vernon Police Department for only four months. He was survived by his parents and brother.
incident_details: Cause: Vehicular assault Weapon: Automobile Offender: Committed suicide
